q1.question: Which of the following statements about dynamic arrays (aka vectors) and linked lists (with head and tail pointers) are true (choose all that apply)?

responses.cache_array: Dynamic arrays generally exhibit poor cache behavior.
responses.cache_list: Linked lists generally exhibit poor cache behavior.
responses.insert_array: Inserting to the front of a dynamic array is always <tt>O(1)</tt>.
responses.insert_list: Inserting to the front of a linked list is always <tt>O(1)</tt>.
responses.append_array: Appending to the back of a dynamic array is always <tt>O(1)</tt>.
responses.append_list: Appending to the back of a linked list is always <tt>O(1)</tt>.
responses.access_array: Accessing an element in the middle of a dynamic array is <tt>O(1)</tt>.
responses.access_list: Accessing an element in the middle of a linked list is <tt>O(1)</tt>.
responses.remove_array: Removing an element from the middle of a dynamic array is <tt>O(n)</tt>.
responses.remove_list: Removing an element from the middle of a doubly-linked list is <tt>O(n)</tt>.

q2.question: While stacks and queues provide both a ____ operation to add items and a ____ operation to remove items from the collection, the former provides ____ ordering while the latter provides ____ ordering.

q3.question:
Below is a C++ function whose purpose is to reverse the contents of the given vector. It does this by copying the elements from the vector into another container and then copying the elements back to the original vector. Fill in the blanks to complete the implementation. 
void reverse(vector<string> &v) {
    ____<string> c;         // 1

    for (auto e : v) {
        ____;               // 2
    }

    ____;                   // 3
    while (____) {          // 4
        ____;               // 5
        ____;               // 6
    }
}

q4.question:
Below is a Python function whose purpose is to reverse the contents of the given list. It does this by copying the elements from the list into another container and then copying the elements back to the original list. Fill in the blanks to complete the implementation. 
def reverse(v):
    c = ____                // 1

    for e in v:
        ____                // 2

    v = ____                // 3
    while ____:             // 4
        ____                // 5

    return ____             // 6
